perturbation.original_text:
Licensor grants to Rogers the non-exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the “Territory”) all entertainment
programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, “Licensed
Programs”) to residential subscribers of Rogers’ digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand (“VOD”) basis.  For clarity, the VOD
service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the “ROD Service”.
perturbation.changed_text:
Licensor grants to Rogers the exclusive license and right to distribute and exhibit in Canada (the “Territory”) all entertainment
programming to which Licensor owns or controls the VOD distribution and exhibition rights in the Territory (collectively, “Licensed
Programs”) to residential subscribers of Rogers’ digital cable television service on a Video-on-Demand (“VOD”) basis. For clarity, the VOD
service that Rogers provides to such subscribers shall hereinafter be referred to as the “ROD Service”.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'non-exclusive' to 'exclusive' directly contradicts the standard definition of a non-exclusive license. A non-exclusive license allows the licensor to grant the same rights to multiple parties, while an exclusive license prohibits this. This change creates ambiguity and potential legal disputes regarding the scope of rights granted to Rogers, conflicting with standard Canadian intellectual property law regarding licensing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Canadian Copyright Act regarding licensing of rights.

perturbation.original_text:
The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be at least twenty-four (24) consecutive hours, or such longer period as may be
agreed to by Rogers and Licensor from time to time (the “Viewing Period”).  Multiple viewings of the Licensed Program shall be permitted
during the Viewing Period for no additional fee and all such viewings shall be considered a single exhibition of the Licensed Program for
the purposes of calculating License Fees hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text:
The viewing period for each Licensed Program shall be exactly twenty-four (24) hours, irrespective of any agreement between Rogers and Licensor (the “Viewing Period”). Multiple viewings of the Licensed Program shall be permitted
during the Viewing Period, subject to additional fees for each view, and all such viewings shall be considered separate exhibitions of the Licensed Program for
the purposes of calculating License Fees hereunder.
perturbation.explanation: By stating the Viewing Period is exactly 24 hours and cannot be altered by any agreement between Rogers and Licensor, and also stipulating additional fees for multiple viewings, this directly contradicts the original allowance for flexibility in the viewing period and no additional fees for multiple viewings. This misaligns with basic contract law principles where parties can mutually agree to terms and conditions. This creates a contractual conflict and ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Basic principles of Canadian contract law regarding mutual agreement and consideration.

perturbation.original_text: Rogers shall be entitled to set off any sums owing to Licensor against any sums owing by Licensor to Rogers hereunder.
perturbation.changed_text: Rogers may, at their discretion, choose to set off sums owed to Licensor against sums owed by Licensor to Rogers, but is under no obligation to do so.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'shall' to 'may, at their discretion', the obligation to set off becomes optional for Rogers. In contract law, 'shall' typically indicates a mandatory action, whereas 'may' indicates a permissive action. This introduces ambiguity and potential disputes, as it's unclear when Rogers is obligated to perform the set-off, conflicting with established legal interpretations of mandatory versus permissive language in contracts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contract interpretation regarding mandatory versus permissive language.
